repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Ozone Depleting Substances
            Phaseout Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts, substantial. Lessons reinforce the
            validity in carefully selecting the participating
            enterprises, based on strong financial viability, and
            sustainability, at appraisal time, to avoid unforeseen
            bankruptcy problems. Global environmental protection
            projects in particular, due to their servicing, and
            marketing nature, require specific public awareness, so that
            issues involved are publicly understood on how protection
            should be implemented. Furthermore, private companies that
            convert technologies, e.g., from chlorofluorocarbon, to the
            production of rigid polyurethane pipe insulation, should
            consider the introduction of environmental labeling on their
            products, through appropriate marketing, and financing
            techniques to be more competitive. And it is important to
            apply technical assistance in the preparation of
            subprojects, to avoid surprises on the extent of
            re-equipment needed, or technical issues required to
            implement the respective technology transfer, under reliable
            cost-effectiveness. Finally, project monitoring and
            management should consider a more rigorous financial
            evaluation, particularly, the financial evaluation
            performance of participating companies, to avoid not only
            bankruptcy problems, but cost overruns, specifically under
            financial crisis and subsequent devaluation circumstances.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Ozone Depleting Substances
            Phase-Out Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Ozone Depleting
            Substances Phase-Out Project is to assist Poland in carrying
            out its Country Program for Ozone Depleting Substances (ODS)
            phase-outs required by the Montreal Protocol and its
            amendments. Specifically the project will assist Poland to:
            a) support the phase-out of the consumption of
            chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) through adoption of proven
            cost-effective CFC-free Technologies; b) support the
            establishment of a national network for
            recovery/reclamation/recycling of refrigerants; and c)
            improve the capacity of the new Ministry of Economy to
            manage and oversee the phase-out of ODS in Poland though
            institutional strengthening. The Project consists of three
            components: a) technology conversion investment component
            which targets priority, cost-effective ODS phase-out
            activities in the refrigeration, foam, and aerosol sector;
            b) a recovery, reclamation and recycling component; and c)
            an institutional strengthening and training components.
